This Issue was created in the now archived Repository org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks by Maarten Meijer
(see https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks/issues/8)

Mylyn philosophy is "eat your own dog food", so now that we moved mylyn to github it makes sense to include a GitHub connector as first class citizen.
Maybe we can invite the current developers as well to participate in mylyn evolution (for example to manage GitHub actions via Mylyn Builds)

title: NA
body:
Thomas Wolf said on the Mylyn-dev list:
	
Sat, 7 Jan, 09:35 (13 days ago)
	
to Matthias, Mylyn, EGit
On 06.01.23 22:19 , Matthias Sohn wrote:
> We didn't yet discuss in the EGit project if we want to take up
> maintenance again
> since Mylyn is revived or if we hand it over to the Mylyn project.
>
> @EGit committers: what do you think?

Sure, if Mylyn wants to maintain and improve it, that's perfectly fine
with me. We never did much with it. I think the only new development in
the past couple of years in the Mylyn connector was my changing the
repository set-up dialog to support GitHub PATs better.

However, see below:
* Keep org.eclipse.egit.github.core where it currently is; don't move
   that one to Mylyn.
* Also move org.eclipse.egit.mylyn.ui to Mylyn.

> On Fri, Jan 6, 2023 at 3:46 PM Wim Jongman <[wim.jongman@gmail.com](mailto:wim.jongman@gmail.com)
> <mailto:[wim.jongman@gmail.com](mailto:wim.jongman@gmail.com)>> wrote:
>
>     Matthias, we are moving the EGit GitHub connector into Mylyn. WDYT?
>
>     PR is here:
>     https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/pull/38
>     <https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/pull/38>
>

This PR also copies org.eclipse.egit.github.core, which is **not** part
of the Mylyn connector. It is a completely separate thing and does not
depend on Mylyn or EGit at all.

I would prefer that one to stay where it is, in the
org.eclipse.egit.github repository. Reasons:

1. It is independent.
2. It uses a BREE of JAVA 8 for Android compatibility.
3. It should be versioned, built, tested, and published independently.

In particular it should be published to maven central.

Some technical things:

The connector makes use of EGit internal classes. EGit has removed it
from x-friends in MANIFEST.MF. Expect a lot of PDE warnings about
discouraged accesses.

I would expect that these accesses to internal classes would be analyzed
and be removed eventually. We'd have to figure out what stable APIs EGit
core and UI would have to provide instead.

EGit does not guarantee anything about internal classes.

Bundle org.eclipse.egit.mylyn.ui, which was removed in the EGit
repository in commit 12a21a6c, should probably also be moved to Mylyn.

There, too, we have internal accesses.

Cheers,

   Thomas

title: PersonProposalProvider searches for possible matches using startsWith(), complicating finding a match
body:
This Issue was created in the now archived Repository org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks by George Lindholm
(see https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks/issues/12)

PersonProposalProvider.matchesSubstring() uses startWith() instead of contains().

This makes it hard to find possible matches.

title: Mylyn notification popups overlap instead of stacking verically on screen when multiple
body:
This Issue was created in the now archived Repository org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks by 
Tikhon Tikhonin
(see https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.commons/issues/2)

using org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.notifications.core.INotificationService.notify(...) from different parts of code (and with quite a big time interval) generate several notification popups, but instead of drawing on top of the ones which are already on the screen, the new one is just gets drawn over existing popups which gives a mess.

I'm not sure. The notification engine of Mylyn contains code to suppress notifications which is not available in JFace AFAIK. However, notifications are probably not a core part of Mylyn. It is a tough call.

title: policy for configuring logging systems such as commons logging
body:
This issue was created in gitlab.eclipse.org by Steffen Pingel
(see https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipsefdn/helpdesk/-/issues/142)

Mylyn integrates with a number of libraries from Apache and other providers many of which use the Apache commons logging framework. To avoid potentially confusing output to appear on the console Mylyn sets the "org.apache.commons.logging.Log" system property to "org.apache.commons.logging.impl.NoOpLog" which suppresses any output (users can override this behavior by explicitly setting the system property in which case it is not modified).
Unfortunately, the logging configuration affects all consumers of commons logging. This can be problematic if other consumers that are not aware of Mylyn's default configuration intend to configure logging in a different way (e.g. [bug 353168](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=353168)).
Since logging is a platform concern it doesn't seem right to have explicit logging configuration in Mylyn. What is the best way to configuring logging? Should there be support in platform? Should each logging system be configured by separate bundles that are included on a distribution package level? Any other suggestions?
Related discussions and bugs: \

- Discussion about SLF4j: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/cross-project-issues-dev/msg05659.html
- Logging output in EPP Java package: 340312
- Common logging service in platform: [bug 292135](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=292135)
- Use SLF4J for p2: [bug 338232](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=338232)
- Bridging legacy logging APIs: http://www.slf4j.org/legacy.html

title: When will the new version be released from main
body:
Hi,

I am facing an issue while using mylyn notifications feed plugin with Java11. The issue is occurring due to required bundle javax.xml.bind in org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.notifications.feed in version 3.25.2 and 3.26 as well. My project has required dependency on jakarta.xml.bind. So now both these dependencies are causing issue during resolution of javax.xml.bind package.

This is already handled in main branch https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/main/mylyn.commons/org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.notifications.feed/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF where javax.xml.bind is not a required dependency.

So, just want to know when the next version from main will be released. Contributing guidelines seems out of date, so not sure how I can I raise a PR for new branch as well.

Can someone please help me on this?

Regards,
Ajay.

title: NA
body:
Here you find the Issue for the next [planed release 3.26](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/.github/issues/5).
And this are the not yet fixed Issues planned for [Mylyn 3.26.0](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/milestone/1).

Contributions are Wellcome.
[Here](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/.github/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) you find how to setup a Development Setup using the Eclipse-Installer.

And com.sun.xml.bind_2.2.0.v20201118-1845.jar is already there in the plugins folder.

title: Hudson Connector - AuthenticationException: Forbidden
body:
Created by Sebastian List: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=412596

=================================================================================
`Hi,
I experiencing authentication errors when trying to connect to a Hudson v3.0.0 server. I cannot refresh Build Plans, nor can I validate my settings. The Stacktrace reads as follows:

org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Unexpected error: Forbidden
	at org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.hudson.core.HudsonCorePlugin.toCoreException(HudsonCorePlugin.java:61)
	at org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.hudson.core.HudsonServerBehaviour.validate(HudsonServerBehaviour.java:908)
	at org.eclipse.mylyn.builds.internal.core.BuildServer.validate(BuildServer.java:369)
`

Sam Davis:
`hanks for the detailed bug report! It looks like the problem is that your server is not returning a 404 for /j_acegi_security_check - could you confirm what response you get when doing a GET to that URL? It's only when getting a 404 there that the connector tries /j_spring_security_check. Since we no longer support versions prior to 3.0.1 we should probably try the latter first and fall back to the former if it fails: https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/21655/. This appears to still work for Hudson 2.2.1.`

Sam Davis:
`Thanks. It sounds like providing the auth header might be a better solution, but it will be a while before we have time to look into that. It could help to speed this up if you submitted a code review. :)`

=================================================================================

I'm having the same problem with my Jenkins Docker instance, v2.391

Disable the 'CSRF Protecttion' "solution" is no longer an option.

title: Connector authentication by token
body:
GitHub/Bamboo/Jira all have the requirement/option to authenticate by token instead of username/password.

The GitHub connector accomplishes this by kludging around the repository setup page code by detecting/intercepting the flow of the setup process.

It would be nice to have this option added to the base code so any connector can access the option, and make it less likely that any future code changes break the github connector

title: Rename Hudson connector to Jenkins connector
body:
Given that the Hudson project is no longer maintained, and announced as obsolete in 2017 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hudson_(software))
And that the source code was archived Feb. 2021 (https://www.eclipse.org/projects/archives.php) .

I would like to suggest that the connector be renamed to Jenkins and any reference to Hudson be dropped.

body:
OK,
now I know why I can not reproduce this.

I use the Mylyn Setup from the Eclipse-Installer and here we do not import all the projects.
We exclude the following path
 - mylyn.builds/org.eclipse.mylyn.hudson.tests/testdata
- mylyn.reviews/tbr
- mylyn.docs
- /org.eclipse.mylyn.java.tests/target

so you need to close or remove the projects located in the excluded path.

Maybe you can use the Eclipse-Installer Mylyn setup the next time you install a new IDE.

>

>

The exclude is only for the "Projects Import" so .project files in that part of the repository are ignored. 

- mylyn.builds/org.eclipse.mylyn.hudson.tests/testdata
  If you import  you get 65 errors in the Error View
- mylyn.reviews/tbr
  Task-based checks (tbr) were not really active, if I remember correctly (similar to the Bugzilla REST Connector)
- mylyn.docs
  we can remove this because this is now an other repository 
- /org.eclipse.mylyn.java.tests/target
  only relevant if you did a maven build an the import the projects

body:
> Let me rephrase that. Why are these "projects" around if it requires special knowledge to import the repository in order to have a clean workspace? What's the purpose of the projects? George
> […](#)

- mylyn.builds/org.eclipse.mylyn.hudson.tests/testdata
  the testdata is used for the setup of the Jenkins Test Instance (jobs/test-ant/config.xml)
- mylyn.reviews/tbr
  this is no longer active but I do not want to delete it yet so I first only do not do a Project Import for the projects
- mylyn.docs
  this is the previous location of https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.docs/ and we can remove this now 
- /org.eclipse.mylyn.java.tests/target
  I found a few other cases where a Maven build left .project files in the build (target) folder and a Project Import added those projects

title: Drop support for Gerrit Connector
body:
Here the reasons.
- Eclipse is moving from git / Gerrit to GitHub / Gitlab
- the actual active Gerrit version is 3.5 or greater (see [Gerrit Supported Versions](https://www.gerritcodereview.com/support.html))
- the mylyn.org instances with version 2.11.10 or 2.13.8 do not work anymore (see Issue #26 we have failing Gerrit tests)

As a first step we remove the Gerrit Connector from the next Mylyn version (3.26).

title: NA
body: The next step, deleting the source, is planned for after 3.26.

title: NA
body: Can we/Should we isolate the connector in a separate repo?

title: NA
body:
Perhaps we should not. I consider the drop of Gerrit support as a decision forced by limited resources.
However mylyn.gerrit subfolder could be good.

Release Engineering work may yet the whole chunk of resources available for a project and it should be automated as much as possible.

Let's employ [dependabot](https://github.com/dependabot) to help us with dependencies management. It already does great job for dependencies from `pom.xml` . 
And there is a [chance](https://github.com/dependabot/dependabot-core/pull/6913) (_**please don't forget to add your supporting comment there**_) that it will be able to manage `.target` manifests as well.

title: Manage External Dependencies
body:
I'm concerned about how external dependencies are managed and in particular about any of the direct-from-maven dependencies that are **generated**.   It's hard to tell which ones in the list are generated versus which ones are actually already well-formed OSGi artifacts:

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/f8a6aa79cac4838c788101fd10f470971ba6bdce/org.eclipse.mylyn-target/mylyn-e4.26.target#L69-L141

I really don't see how we can properly coordinate versions of libraries  in SimRel when projects independently of each other  generate wrappers for non OSGi-libraries.  What's generated depends on the BND recipe:

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/f8a6aa79cac4838c788101fd10f470971ba6bdce/org.eclipse.mylyn-target/mylyn-e4.26.target#L132-L141

Each project may and likely will use a different recipe which appears likely to result in many different artifacts that use the same key such that they appear to be the same artifact from a p2 perspective but are actually different.   That's not just a problem for SimRel but a problem in general when installing such content into any installation.

Here's an example:

https://github.com/eclipse/tm4e/blob/ac34c5f440f95e1046ecb69b1c3c5c8514cb4a86/target-platform/tm4e-target.target#L44-L52

Making all the package imports optional in the recipe is convenient but is highly likely to be wrong:
```
Import-Package:        *;resolution:=optional
```

In any case, these artifacts are not even being PGP signed as far as I can tell:

https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/archive/reports-extra/mylyn/download.eclipse.org/mylyn/stage/latest/index.html

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/235417047-2222ba54-42a5-48a5-bb15-4347a0d2d206.png)

It's also strange to see EGit's GitHub integration come from a Maven repository rather than more directly from EGit's downloads:

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/f8a6aa79cac4838c788101fd10f470971ba6bdce/org.eclipse.mylyn-target/mylyn-e4.26.target#L126-L130

https://download.eclipse.org/egit/github/

I feel that these generated direct-from-maven dependencies are opening up a new can of worms, and we've not even been able to fully manage the existing can of worms...

title: NA
body:
Thank you for opening this issue, I'm also not happy with the way we consume libraries from maven, and tried to find a recommended way to do it but failed. 

So, how should we properly declare an external maven dependency @merks ?

title: NA
body:
You should specify `missingManifest="error"` so that it fails for anything that is **not** available as an OSGi artifact:

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/f8a6aa79cac4838c788101fd10f470971ba6bdce/org.eclipse.mylyn-target/mylyn-e4.26.target#LL69C81-L69C81

Anything that fails you should get from Orbit.  I am current prototyping building a repository with such generated OSGi artifacts using an m2e target with BND recipes, but that is a work in progress that I will continue today...

Unless there is a **compelling** need for the absolute newest versions of these dependencies, I suggest you look here for those dependencies here:

https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/simrel-orbit/

If you get them from there, that also eliminate the need to enable PGP signing...

title: NA
body:
> Anything that fails you should get from Orbit. 

I don't think that's a good suggestion, as orbit is always lacking behind and there is no compelling reason for a project to depend on orbit releases if the artifact is on maven, there might be some exceptions where it does not work, but in general the goal should be to get the OSGi metadata into the original library beside the following recommendations:

1. **Never (!)** use require bundle for a third party dependency, but an import package with appropriate version range (either consumer or provider)
2. Do not include third party dependencies in any `feature.xml` as dependencies will be pulled in anyways if used
3. if wrapping is required, choose a custom prefix, e.g.  `Bundle-SymbolicName:   mylyn.${mvnGroupId}.${mvnArtifactId}` and review the resulting manifest if you publish them.

That way OSGi (and P2) can always substitute / reuse an alternative version of the artifact, in the worst-case there will be different wrapped ones with same content but that's nothing unusual/forbidden/dangerous, that's what OSGi was designed for!

title: NA
body:
> Unless there is a **compelling** need for the absolute newest versions of these dependencies

Ed, this is very different from what we discussed previously. Previously your message was: [In the end, I think the process is very clear. **Everyone use the latest version**](https://github.com/merks/simrel-maven/issues/3#issuecomment-1497228678). 

Let's imagine that Mylyn has a **compelling** need - what should we do then?

title: NA
body:
> Let's imagine that Mylyn has a compelling need - what should we do then?

Just see above, if you choose a different BSN (at best with a project prefix) there is absolutely no reason to not use a latest custom wrapped version (but also consider the last item in the list!)

title: NA
body:
@ruspl-afed 

I tried to avoid drawing attention to what TM4E is doing because that looks like anarchy to me and is not what the Platform is doing.   But now we're sliding down that slippery slope and will need to deal with that too.   So we need the rule:

 **No generated Maven dependencies allowed.**

What @laeubi suggests will mean every project creates its own key/version of generated IUs, so no collisions.  But **lots** of duplicates, but at least they won't look like duplicates.   If projects avoid bundle requirements then  which variant ends up on the train seems indeterminate.  It will be hard for projects to get those bundles into their repositories though, unless they include all requirements, in which case they will fill up their repo with the entire Eclipse platform and any other project on which they depended; maybe there is a solution for that too.  If the generated package exports aren't versioned, one cannot control which version of you end up with, so that seems like a new form or anarchy.

Should we really start sliding down this slope without understanding what is at the end of that runway?

title: NA
body:
> So we need the rule:
> No generated Maven dependencies allowed.

we absolutely don't, see above for a simple list of recommendations. This won't result in duplicates if all projects use the same version and semantic imports. And even if there are some duplicates this does not harm anything.

> If the generated package exports aren't versioned, one cannot control which version of you end up with, so that seems like a new form or anarchy.

The automatic generated package exports always have a version.

title: NA
body:
>  as orbit is always lacking behind and there is no compelling reason for a project to depend on orbit releases

I think this is the key. What we need is the way to register approved 3rd party relatively quick, but still have it centralized to avoid variations and allow reuse.

> And even if there are some duplicates this does not harm anything.

For me it is similar to situation where every project forks a class from Platform to its own package and then they are happy loaded together, since OSGi allows them to do so.

title: NA
body:
@laeubi  

If I say we absolutely do need such a rule and you say we absolute don't, then that is the end of the discussion isn't it?  Then there is no point is reasoning further because the lines are etched in the concrete.  Then we will have to go to the supreme court of justice and get a ruling.  It unfortunately feels futile to even have a discussion because only certain facts seem to matter.  We saw the problem with gson duplicates last release cycle, yet you assert duplicates do not harm anything.  At best they do no harm, other than bloat, but at worst they cause very hard to fix problems that we can of course blame on bad metadata, bad semantic versioning and other bad things that bad people do, but things that one one can actually solve as well.

@ruspl-afed 

Yes, the idea is to produce update sites that can be quickly (in a matter of minutes) be produced and that are automatically updated to the latest version by a generator that looks at maven central.

You can see I've already been doing that:

https://git.eclipse.org/c/oomph/org.eclipse.oomph.incubator.git/log/
https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator/commits/master/eclipse.platform.releng.prereqs.sdk

But if centralized-except-for-maven is evil and decentralized generation and consumption is the only valid solution, then there is no discussion left to have, although a **clear** set of policies is need in either case...

title: NA
body:
> we absolutely don't, see above for a simple list of recommendations. This won't result in duplicates if all projects use the same version and semantic imports. And even if there are some duplicates this does not harm anything.

We already know this is *not* true - otherwise I wouldn't have had to spend time respinning stuff to get rid of dup gson.

title: NA
body:
> If I say we absolutely do need such a rule and you say we absolute don't, then that is the end of the discussion isn't it? 

No I'm sure we will find enough :+1:  in some way or another that there will be such a rule because people simply don't care do do things right and instead inventing new "rules" to make things even worse.

>  It unfortunately feels futile to even have a discussion because only certain facts seem to matter.

I presented some technical facts, but you argument with "another form of anarchy" (while this is actually a form of _autonomy_) so yes it seems that some specific _feelings_ seem to matter much more than facts.

> But if centralized-except-for-maven is evil and decentralized generation and consumption is the only valid solution, then there is no discussion left to have, although a clear set of policies is need in either case...

The only evil is to require rules to solve issues that won't occur without them, the simrel is so used to the "one-dependency-for-all" that projects simply don't care anymore about dependency management and correct usage of imports as they can easily offload it to others (especially you), the problem is that each of these "offloads" takes away autonomy from projects and [increase the bus factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_factor).

And to make it clear, it was not me that states " so we need the rule" that really feels like an absolute statement than a recommendation... So how can one respond to such as with another absolute statement?
Sad enough if **you** made such a statement is fine if **other** do so they are always promote the absolute evil ...

> We already know this is not true - otherwise I wouldn't have had to spend time respinning stuff to get rid of dup gson.

Sorry I told the corresponding projects long before the issue happens that they use a wrong version range, but it was ignored so please don't twist the cause with the problem here, so these "issues" where not introduced by the fact that we have had duplicate versions, the duplicate versions where introduced because they **where explicitly requested**!

And think what, it was finally fixed (to some small extend) as I have recommended many times before and it **just worked**! So we don't need more _rules_, we need more _recommendations_ in how to handle such situations properly beside from "I found something on SO/Google/outdated blog post/...  that seem to fix my issue even though I don't understand why".

title: NA
body:
This does not feel like a discussion focused on a solution.   More compelling would be to propose a well-formed vision of a better solution.

From what I understand the solution you've recommended is that each project use a project-unique name for their generated "wrappers", that the generated wrappers version all their package exports, and that no other bundle or feature ever reference those wrapper names.  Does this fairly characterize what you see as the best/ideal/only solution?

Unfortunately no one has been doing that. In fact the default behavior (without a recipe) doesn't do that either.  This appears to me a formula where 70 projects will actually and most definitely produce 70 variants of the "same library".  Unfortunately, each variant of the 'same library" might use a different recipe, e.g., optional imports are the default, but probably not correct, so some might do that differently.  In the end, the variants won't generally all be the same.  Which one(s) end up aggregated and actually installed appears mostly non-deterministic as well.  All that might well not cause any actual visible problems.  But it feels like a significant risk to me and if it does cause problems those are not easily fixed.

Of course I don't that argue "do the wrapping in a central place" is 100% ideal either.   You've noted some of the significant organizational drawbacks.  I don't see any technical risks for SimRel, though perhaps I've overlooked them.

title: NA
body:
> This does not feel like a discussion focused on a solution

The problem is that a _solution_ was proposed before the problem was _understood_, and that's a major problem in software development in general. So everything that starts with "we must do this" is obviously nothing focused in a finding solution because it already implies it... but that might be a personal feeling of me.

> From what I understand the solution you've recommended is that each project use a project-unique name for their generated "wrappers", that the generated wrappers version all their package exports, and that no other bundle or feature ever reference those wrapper names. Does this fairly characterize what you see as the best/ideal/only solution?

It was claimed that there is no recommendation, so I tried to give some general advice how such situation (purely from a technical point of view) are handled in a flexible way. Whether or not this is assumed "best" is (for me) out of scope, because this depends on so many other factors.

At least it solves what was implied as a problem here as "how we can properly coordinate versions of libraries in SimRel when projects independently of each other generate wrappers for non OSGi-libraries" ... maybe is misunderstood the problem, or there are other concerns not addressed, this is not clear to me at this point.

So to summarize, I think this is a very good approach, and it would solve the problem, where the details might wary (e.g. depending on the deployment strategies used, a "product" has different demands to a "plugin" or a "library" type)

> Unfortunately no one has been doing that. 

I'm doing that from day 1 where this feature was added to Tycho+m2e and this is already quite a long time now. But the feature was designed to give liberty to their users to use it in a different way, so it is not the only way.

> In fact the default behavior (without a recipe) doesn't do that either.

The defaults are the smallest possible valuable increment, as every default it can work for many cases but fail for others. nerveless **you can insert any instructions** here including what often is refereed to as a "receipe", there is literally no restriction!

>  This appears to me a formula where 70 projects will actually and most definitely produce 70 variants of the "same library". 

First you propose that each project will use all the dependencies what is just not the case and as mentioned before, if it is very common to use such a lib, it is much more valuable to add such metadata in the library directly, wrapping was never meant as a general purpose solution, it is some kind of band-aid for libs you want to prototype, or no one will produce new release or alike, nerveless you can of course use it for other ways. and if you combine this with the Target-Reference-Location you can even share this among as many projects as you like.

> Unfortunately, each variant of the 'same library" might use a different recipe, e.g., optional imports are the default, but probably not correct, so some might do that differently. 

The point is that this literally does not matter, as such a wrapping never ever (well at least if you want to save you from trouble), should become part of your bundle-contract, you simply do import-package with proper version range and then your result will not depend on that (probably wrong shaped) wrapping!

So if I build something (like the simrel), I probably even keep a list of correctly and audited wrappings for a certain lib, or some time later there will be a new release of that lib that already carry the data, it simply do not matter for the artifact that use this for **the sole purpose of compile and development** from a different source!

> Which one(s) end up aggregated and actually installed appears mostly non-deterministic as well.

Software usually always is deterministic. So if there is something that behaves that way it might be worth to fix that.

> I don't see any technical risks for SimRel, though perhaps I've overlooked them.

The problem is, that there is already a "rule" that one should not depend on content from "the simrel" but if I remember correctly we have already had some issues because people simply do, especially we had dependencies from mylin / old orbits releases specifically see:

https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator/blob/b5b94800896102d044d232165e8f72e2aac4f5da/eclipse.platform.releng.prereqs.sdk/eclipse-sdk-prereqs.target#L75-L79

also we have happens-before relationship already here:
https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator/blob/b5b94800896102d044d232165e8f72e2aac4f5da/eclipse.platform.releng.prereqs.sdk/eclipse-sdk-prereqs.target#L49

So from a project point of view (even though maybe convenient) there is a high risk of unnoticed dependencies, even worse, once you have installed such service, you can hardly get rid of it, so from now on we:

1. Have to maintain Orbit release
2. Even older releases because some (accidentally) still rely on it 
3. Soon the "new central wrapping service" that will let people think it might be easier to use that service instead of helping projects maintain OSGi meta-data at first place.

title: NA
body:
Let’s call the new repo for generated artifacts “audited wrappings” and let’s hope one day soon we can tear off the band aides to find it empty. 

SimRel/EPP really does make products from dozens of projects and the people doing that do have knowledge and experience with the problem history associated with that activity such that we might be assumed to have some understanding.

title: Please let us put the dist.qualifier into a profile and use this in the maven pipeline build.
body:
Please let us put the dist.qualifier into a profile and use this in the maven pipeline build.
We need a default that we can use for a local build and also set the dist.timestampProvider to empty.
Otherwise we can have locale create artifacts that conflicts with artifacts from a staging repository.

_Originally posted by @BeckerFrank in https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/108#issuecomment-1533336944_

title: NA
body:
I found that part of some previous problems come from the following scenario.

1.  create a local Mylyn workspace and change some code but not committing the changes back to the repository
2. use mvn clean install to build a local update p2 repository
    with
    `
    <dist.qualifier>'N'yyyyMMdd-HHmm</dist.qualifier>
    <dist.timestampProvider>jgit</dist.timestampProvider>
` the jars get a timestamp from the last commit

3. use file:///... to install this in an other Eclipse Installation using a bundle pool.
4. use the pipeline to build a new nightly/staging version

Now you have in the bundle pool a jar with uncommitted changes but can not overwrite it.

Thougths?

title: Support a stable repository structure for publishing builds
body:
One approach is to reuse JustJ's repository publishing infrastructure.  I can help integrate that if that's what folks want.  But before investing effort, I want to be **sure** that's really what folks want.  I can provide details here, but for today my time to do that is limited...

Here's one example of how it would work:

https://ci.eclipse.org/emf/job/build/

The build is parameterized:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/236128178-2a65c7a1-7907-4bd5-950c-d38875594cf4.png)

The most relevant thing here is that you can specify nightly, milestone, or release and whether to promote the build.  E.g., for a PR build, one does not need to sign, probably shouldn't in fact because it slows down the build and doing that allows a contributor to grab and redistribute signed content with their "hooks" in it, and should not publish it.  

The versions are controlled by the version of a specified/designate feature so one only needs to properly increment feature versions to provide, in the end, new release versions.  One can also control which bundles/features are listed in the documentation; e.g., omit the 3rd party things.

title: NA
body:
@BeckerFrank 

Maybe it would be good to create a dedicated issue for the baseline thing.   Oomph's setup infrastructure also allows a baseline to be set up using a targlets and this can use the previous release update site directly.  Not only that, it reuses the bundle pool for building the API baseline and it's highly likely that most of the bundles will already be in the pool such that it's hyper fast.  I'm not sure if you care about the details of how the API baseline is set?

@BeckerFrank @ruspl-afed

body:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/236632484-8d4cc3b1-5c9a-4f42-a20a-bd7a6ae63a8b.png)

I.e., just specify the root features, which pulls in the transitive requirements, so this assumes all the plugins are required from these roots.  The URL, once there is a release, will always be the latest release.  So not much ever needs to change, nothing special is needed as input, and it's super fast...

title: Don't include test bundles and features in the update site
body:
I thought I'd make this a separate issue so that you folks can decide if you really want the test bundles and features in the update site.

I was trying the extent to which other update sites need to be available up install the Mylyn content, but quickly noticed that the tests have dependencies that are hard to track down and that this just gets in the way of the analysis.  I suspect that probably no one wants to install tests but maybe they want them in a target platform.   But no one extends the test bundles, then I think it doesn't make sense to include these things in the update site...

title: NA
body:
Removing the things in the tests category and trying again I still get surprises like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/236760090-c6140df5-404d-44b2-8197-9064a20d6678.png)

This makes me think that the org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.tck feature is a test artifact...

So removing that too and I can see that all remaining Mylyn bundles and features are installable if these addition 4 repositories are available:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/236761778-bf76a9a0-3e12-42e7-b7f1-f2389c2a6b30.png)

That's also the case if there is a release train repository available, even an older one:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/208716/236762508-048141c3-c6ba-472c-8f02-2240221b50ca.png)

title: NA
body:
Yes, I think we can try to remove the whole "Mylyn Tests" Category from the Updatesite.
Maybe we should also remove the "Mylyn SDK and Framework" or at least remove no longer needed parts.
Thougths?

title: NA
body: Yes, I think we can remove tests from publishing and also fix/remove corresponding features.

title: Plan for the maintenance of org.eclipse.egit.github.core
body:
The source of this plugins is here: 

https://git.eclipse.org/c/egit/egit-github.git/tree/org.eclipse.egit.github.core

But all the other projects have migrated to Mylyn, except this one project.

Do we really expect the EGit project to keep maintaining this one essential bundle?  Their update site doesn't even include a source bundle so it's really hard to work with this thing and it contains lots of really useful functionality.

https://download.eclipse.org/egit/github/updates/

 It's already included in Mylyn's own update site, so wouldn't it be better if this bundle were maintained by the Mylyn project?

title: NA
body: @BeckerFrank  @wimjongman , I agree with Ed @merks.  The mentioned bundle has no dependencies to the rest of EGit and defines API for GiHub. After migrating others, it seems natural to move this to Mylyn as well.

title: NA
body:
We got the following mail:
Von: Wim Jongman <notifications@github.com>
Betreff: Aw: [eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn] "Appropriate" GitHub connector in mylyn.tasks (Issue #18)
Datum: 20. Januar 2023 um 12:16:13 MEZ
An: "eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn" <org.eclipse.mylyn@noreply.github.com>
Kopie: Frank Becker <eclipse@frank-becker.de>,  Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Antwort an: "eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn" <reply+ADEPFUH7PKFEIFANX6KXREWB26VH3EVBNHHFUSNZLI@reply.github.com>


Thomas Wolf said on the Mylyn-dev list:
Sat, 7 Jan, 09:35 (13 days ago)
to Matthias, Mylyn, EGit On 06.01.23 22:19 , Matthias Sohn wrote:
We didn't yet discuss in the EGit project if we want to take up maintenance again since Mylyn is revived or if we hand it over to the Mylyn project.
[@eGit](https://github.com/eGit) committers: what do you think?
Sure, if Mylyn wants to maintain and improve it, that's perfectly fine with me. We never did much with it. I think the only new development in the past couple of years in the Mylyn connector was my changing the repository set-up dialog to support GitHub PATs better.
However, see below:
	•	Keep org.eclipse.egit.github.core where it currently is; don't move that one to Mylyn.
	•	Also move org.eclipse.egit.mylyn.ui to Mylyn.
On Fri, Jan 6, 2023 at 3:46 PM Wim Jongman <[wim.jongman@gmail.com](mailto:wim.jongman@gmail.com) [mailto:[wim.jongman@gmail.com](mailto:wim.jongman@gmail.com)](mailto:%5Bwim.jongman@gmail.com%5D(mailto:wim.jongman@gmail.com))> wrote:
Matthias, we are moving the EGit GitHub connector into Mylyn. WDYT?

PR is here:
https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/pull/38
<https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/pull/38>
This PR also copies org.eclipse.egit.github.core, which is not part of the Mylyn connector. It is a completely separate thing and does not depend on Mylyn or EGit at all.
I would prefer that one to stay where it is, in the org.eclipse.egit.github repository. Reasons:
	1.	It is independent.
	2.	It uses a BREE of JAVA 8 for Android compatibility.
	3.	It should be versioned, built, tested, and published independently.
In particular it should be published to maven central.
Some technical things:
The connector makes use of EGit internal classes. EGit has removed it from x-friends in MANIFEST.MF. Expect a lot of PDE warnings about discouraged accesses.
I would expect that these accesses to internal classes would be analyzed and be removed eventually. We'd have to figure out what stable APIs EGit core and UI would have to provide instead.
EGit does not guarantee anything about internal classes.
Bundle org.eclipse.egit.mylyn.ui, which was removed in the EGit repository in commit 12a21a6c, should probably also be moved to Mylyn.
There, too, we have internal accesses.
Cheers,
Thomas
— Reply to this email directly, [view it on GitHub](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/18#issuecomment-1398241111), or [unsubscribe](https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ADEPFUGP4VTI2KTODBXEXV3WTJXX3ANCNFSM6AAAAAATNDVZFQ). You are receiving this because you authored the thread.

Please note that in the past this functionality defined in the Mylyn Team connector must actually be implemented in the specific repository connector itself.
Mylyn used to be hosted in eclipse.org git (using git connector) but is now hosted on GitHub (using GitHub connector).
So maybe this functionality is not (yet) implemented in the GitHub connector.

The Github connector was recently 'acquired' by the Mylyn project so it is not yet a first class citizen, so maybe this is just not implemented. I'm traveling so have not time to dig deeper.

body:
This is not Connector specific!

we implement the following extension to include the MylynCommitMessageProvider into the egit UI 

`<extension`
`      point="org.eclipse.egit.ui.commitMessageProvider">`
`   <commitMessageProvider`
`         class="org.eclipse.egit.internal.mylyn.ui.commit.MylynCommitMessageProvider">`
`   </commitMessageProvider>`
`</extension>`

With the following steps I am able to get the Commit Message.

1. deactivate the Task
2. make sure that theCommit Message Text box is empty
3. activate the Task
4. switch to an other branch

title: NA
body:
I'd like to update all the branding images used for the features but it also seems like a good idea to keep all the original artifacts in the zip file unzipped into a git repository.   Some possible choices are 

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/.github
https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn
https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/mylyn-website

If hosted in the website, one could reference the images without relying on raw access to the images, but the website is pretty stale and I'm not sure the future plans for it...

Thoughts/preferences?

BTW, I think the setup should include a project for mylyn-website.  Also, it seems https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.docs has kind of split off to have an independent life of it's own, and it can't easily exist in the same workspace because each has a different *.target file.

title: NA
body:
> I'd like to update all the branding images used for the features but it also seems like a good idea to keep all the original artifacts in the zip file unzipped into a git repository. Some possible choices are
> 
> https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/.github https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/mylyn-website
> 
> If hosted in the website, one could reference the images without relying on raw access to the images, but the website is pretty stale and I'm not sure the future plans for it...
> 
> Thoughts/preferences?

We need to activate GitHub pages to use the repository [mylyn-website](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/mylyn-website) and ask for the right redirect. I have create the first [two issues](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/mylyn-website/issues) so feel free to add some more.

> 
> BTW, I think the setup should include a project for mylyn-website.

Unfortunately, I have not yet published my changes.
> Also, it seems https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn.docs has kind of split off to have an independent life of it's own, and it can't easily exist in the same workspace because each has a different *.target file.

It seems to me that it would be better to have Mylyn and Mylyn Docs in two separate GitHub organizations. With all the consequences like duplicate setups, but also the better visibility of the independence of Mylyn Docs from the rest of Mylyn.

The .github repository doesn't make that clear enough to me.

FYI, as soon as I publish a build as I discussed in https://github.com/merks/simrel-maven/issues/5 Mylyn's build is going to be broken.  I have tested that the build (minus running the tests) completes locally with the new bundle names, but I want to warn you in case you want to scream about it.  😱

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman @ruspl-afed 

I continue to see this problem and I don't understand where the commits approve are?  I don't see them locally nor here:

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/commits/main

Where are these commits and will they be in main soon?

title: NA
body: The commits are still in their branches. We have two variants of changes: one was not approved and another cannot pass pipeline.

title: NA
body: I see, I'm used to seeing PR from a fork!

title: NA
body: @merks it is merged now, please try on your side with the nearest milestone build

title: NA
body: The problem doesn't happen anymore.

title: remove IStartup Interface
body:
In mylyn we have three IStartup implementations. Two of the three are unused and we could delete them.
We can convert the used BuildsStartup to an other implementation.

title: Ensure that we have proper "License vetting status check" configuration
body:
This is reminder to revisit the consequences of #152 

In the best case IP team will fix the Dash tool
Or we will need to reconfigure our "License vetting status check"

title: NA
body: @merks I have an anesthetic for our main pipeline, see #158 , it is waiting for approval from @BeckerFrank | @wimjongman

title: NA
body: Not needed anymore, IP Lab issues are closed

title: Old Guava
body: I'm not sure what to do about com.google.guava which comes from here and is a really old version restricted to bundle-version="[21.0.0,22.0.0)"  what should we do?    We have old gson and other old things.  How best to update these things?

title: NA
body: My vote would be to ditch guava completely and just use the native java libraries (with a dash of apache).

title: NA
body: I would also like to remove guava, but I'm not sure if we can do it right now.

title: NA
body: Yes it’s work to eliminate and at best a no-op. Likely only a small highly stable subset is used such that removing version constraints is okay and expedient.

title: NA
body: Sorry, one test I should have done before is to test installing all the Mylyn features.  This turned up a few problems, like the the rcp thing needing the old logging thing, and not all of the latest guava's dependencies being available.  I will provide a fix for that immediately.

title: NA
body:
When I analyze why there are two versions of gson, while testing aggregating the latest Mylyn repository, I can see this:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/208716/5b7b48f4-fb8b-4dfc-a83f-2c175b6d9386)

One is the direct-from-maven version and the other is the orbit version of the same bundles...

So I will remove the includes/imports from the Mylyn features, but ensure that a version of gson is available in the repository

title: Features in Mylyn that aren't in SimRel
body:
Hi folks,

I [just added](https://github.com/eclipse-packaging/packages/pull/24) most of the features of SimRel to the EPP, but I found that a bunch of features in the Mylyn update site are not being contributed to SimRel.

On a quick pass AFAICT these items don't appear in SimRel but do appear in [Mylyn](https://download.eclipse.org/mylyn/updates/milestone/S202305240755/) (as contributed to 2023-06 M3):

- org.eclipse.egit.mylyn (xref  #134)
- org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla_feature
- org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.activity
- org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature
- org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.index

I assume especially the egit and github features are or should one day be part of SimRel and the EPPs.

title: NA
body:
I added the 5 selected at the bottom (available features but not contributed to SimRel)  just now, but the other two selected were already present:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/208716/78196c65-9ec0-4fd7-a448-65a8c88c7250)

https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/simrel/org.eclipse.simrel.build/+/202144

title: NA
body:
Thanks Ed for the quick turnaround - I am reviewing what exactly should be in EPP based on this in https://github.com/eclipse-packaging/packages/issues/19. 

Weird thing is that `org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature` does not appear in simrel.aggran, I would have expected it around here:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/679236/e72da69e-78ed-4324-ba9d-2e3158e67bc4)

title: NA
body:
I may be going crazy - but `org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature` doesn't appear in SimRel output https://download.eclipse.org/staging/2023-06/

Is there a SimRel / aggregator issue here preventing it from appearing in the output?

title: NA
body:
Yes, there's something crazy going on.  Searching for the name indicates that EGit UI bundle appears to be providing that capability!

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/208716/278db193-4a28-4365-b6f8-00104568e1c3)

@msohn

If I lock in the versions, that likely will help.  I'll get back to you in a few minutes...

title: NA
body:
I am guessing the issue is here: https://git.eclipse.org/r/plugins/gitiles/egit/egit/+/refs/heads/master/org.eclipse.egit.ui/META-INF/p2.inf#10

introduced probably as a way to uninstall mylyn.github when upgrading https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/egit/egit/+/194240

title: NA
body:
Yes, only p2.inf could create such a strange capability in a bundle...  I've locked in the version and categorized all the features:

https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/simrel/org.eclipse.simrel.build/+/202158

So when the aggregation finishes it should be in more sensible shape:

https://ci.eclipse.org/simrel/job/simrel.runaggregator.pipeline/

title: NA
body:
(that p2.inf also covers `org.eclipse.egit.mylyn.feature.group`)

The locked down versions ensure that the feature really makes into into the SimRel p2 directory.

*But* it still causes downstream problems, for example if I add a line into the product that says:

`<feature id="org.eclipse.egit.mylyn" installMode="root"/>`

I will get install error like this when trying to build EPP:

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.eclipse.tycho:tycho-packaging-plugin:2.7.1:build-qualifier-aggregator (default-build-qualifier-aggregator) on project epp.package.cpp: Execution default-build-qualifier-aggregator of goal org.eclipse.tycho:tycho-packaging-plugin:2.7.1:build-qualifier-aggregator failed: Could not resolve feature org.eclipse.egit.mylyn_null; Path to dependency:
[ERROR] 
```

(there is indeed nothing after `Path to dependency:`) 

Which means I would have to be explicit about version numbers in the product files.

Since egit has dealt with the removal of the bundles this way in the past, perhaps we should be renaming (id only) these 2 features going forward? For `org.eclipse.egit.mylyn` it would have secondary benefit of moving it into mylyn's namespace.

WDYT?

title: NA
body:
PS The alternative is that egit removes their p2.inf entries, which will resolve most cases, but I don't know long term if that leaves us in a better or worse shape than simply renaming now.

cc @msohn

title: NA
body: I think we need @msohn to explain the purpose of this thing.   Changing IDs is also disruptive...

title: NA
body:
What might/could work is to have in the p2.inf of the product a negative requirement on the very specific version provided by EGit's capability:

https://wiki.eclipse.org/Equinox/p2/Customizing_Metadata#Capability_Advice:

title: NA
body: No probably a dumb idea.  I would want to exclude the EGit bundle then and that won't work either...

title: NA
body: Dumb question, is there a 'Eclipse for Dummies' book that can help me make sense of this discussion?

title: NA
body:
@gnl42 

Sorry, you'd have to learn quite a few concepts around how p2 works and how represents requirements and resolve requirements; I don't know of any good succinct guide for that.  Suffice to say in this case that EGit has made one of its bundles look like it is a feature such that it creates confusion when trying to refer to the actual feature provided by Mylyn.  So either EGit should remove what it did or Mylyn should consider using a different ID for the feature.

title: NA
body:
We should probably not be in the egit namespace. Is there time to rename the bundles and features to o.e.mylyn,egit? 

see
https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/18

title: NA
body: I think we've become a bit distracted with renaming org.eclipse.egit.mylyn to org.eclipse.mylyn.egit which is all fine and good but has nothing to do with this issue.  The issue here is that EGit's UI bundle is providing a capability named `org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature.feature.group` and either it needs to stop doing that or we have to rename the org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature.feature.group feature.  Note that this is a feature, org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature.feature.group,  in Mylyn's namespace and there is no compelling reason to rename it other than EGit colliding with it.

title: NA
body:
I've pushed this change to Gerrit to address the problem in EGit:

https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/egit/egit/+/202164

title: NA
body:
> I think we've become a bit distracted with renaming org.eclipse.egit.mylyn to org.eclipse.mylyn.egit which is all fine and good but has nothing to do with this issue. 

Yes and no - if both `org.eclipse.egit.mylyn` *and* `org.eclipse.mylyn.github.feature` are renamed that would be ok.

> I've pushed this change to Gerrit to address the problem in EGit:

This is the ideal solution for the 2023-06 release and I hope @msohn has time to review and integrate it. Thanks Ed for submitting it.

title: NA
body: The Gerrit changes for https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/egit/egit/+/202164 are merged, so the RC1 contribution should fix this problem.

title: NA
body:
This seems to be done now, all the features are in and egit have merged in https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/165#issuecomment-1568379730

See https://github.com/eclipse-packaging/packages/pull/26 for the updated contents of what parts of mylyn are in which package.

title: NA
body: Yes that class has a logic flaw. Probably caused by #166

title: NA
body: Thanks for fixing so many of these errors. I have identified one additional one which I raised in #186

title: Could not load repository template extension contributed by 'org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla.ide' with connectorKind 'bugzilla'
body:
In a fresh install/workspace I tried running (what will be) EPP 2023-06 M3 for C/C++ Developers and I get this error message in the log at startup:

```
!ENTRY org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.core 4 0 2023-05-25 18:59:18.663
!MESSAGE Unexpected error while loading repository template extensions
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.core 4 0 2023-05-25 18:59:18.663
!MESSAGE Could not load repository template extension contributed by 'org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla.ide' with connectorKind 'bugzilla'
```

Maybe this is a consequence of `org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla.ide` being included in the `ide_feature` https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/adbfdf433caeccd3e808cad3aabb37c52d447411/mylyn.context/org.eclipse.mylyn.ide-feature/feature.xml#L42 but the rest of the bugzilla feature is not installed?

title: NA
body:
This happens in the selected code when there is no registered "repKind":

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/208716/47d95214-b256-455c-9cd3-554e551e16df)

We can see that while the bugzilla.id plugin registers the template, the bugzilla.core  registers the repository kind, so when that's not installed, we see an exception.

I think the bugzilla.ide plugin should require the bugzilla.core, and probably bugzilla.ui...

title: NA
body:
> Maybe this is a consequence of org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla.ide being included in the ide_feature

AFAICT from #178 the change now pulls in bugzilla all the time when using ide_feature. I think it should not pull in any of bugzilla and I have provided a fix for that in #180

title: NA
body:
Maybe we should rework all the Entries "Mylyn SDK and Framework" because some / all are no longer needed.
Most of them were created at a time where Mylyn has many other people working on external connector and we want to provide a way tho use only parts of Mylyn.

I think now that we use Oomph for Workspace Setup we now longer really need this.

Thougths?

title: NA
body: I would suggest to introduce standard "YYY Developer Resources" features that contains source bundles and then remove "SDK" features.

title: NA
body:
> I would suggest to introduce standard "YYY Developer Resources" features that contains source bundles and then remove "SDK" features.

+1

title: Mylyn connectors install page only offers old/broken versions
body:
Opening the mylyn connector discovery UI by doing:

1. Show Task Repositories view
2. Press Add Task Repository button ![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/679236/3ac77c33-b60d-4fb3-aba2-f422787a5235)
3. Press Install More Connectors

This is the UI I am presented with:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/679236/d61018c1-cb87-4b6e-94e9-0421f2c092f9)

Every entry in this list is either not installable (Foglyn is disabled, see #166 for probable reason, others fail to install due to version mismatches), installs but is completely non-functional (Mantis installs, but then a lot of Guava errors are encountered after restart), or installs an older version (all Eclipse provided ones are old version 3.25.2.v20200814-0512).

In the error log I can see it accessing the 3.25 snapshot of Mylyn to fill this discovery window, I guess that the URLs in https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/adbfdf433caeccd3e808cad3aabb37c52d447411/org.eclipse.mylyn.discovery-directory/plugin.xml#L80 need updating?

title: NA
body:
When this discovery feature was introduced there were wild dreams of a marketplace for connectors that would provide a business model for Tasktop Inc. That never materialized and maintaining this up to date list for the connectors proved to be a maintenance burden with little effect. Meanwhile most connectors are also listed in the Eclipse Marketplace and maintained there by their owners.

So a radical proposal for removing this maintenance burden from the Mylyn team:
- try and make Mylyn connectors a category in the Eclipse Marketplace
- create API for questioning a specific category in the Marketplace plugin
- simplify the mylyn discovery plugin to query the Eclipse Marketplace directly rather than duplicating the maintenance effort.
@wimjongman what do you think?

title: NA
body: Even more radical: I think we should drop the connector discovery logic altogether.

title: NA
body: +1 for removal of the functionality.

title: NA
body:
+1 for ditching it.

We should also take a look at cleaning up/remove/re-create https://wiki.eclipse.org/Mylyn/Extensions

title: NA
body: +1 for remove in 3.27, for upcoming 3.26.1 let's consider anesthetic #176

title: NA
body:
The update in #176 is better as it removes all the errors, broken plug-ins, etc. But it does leave this confusing error message that reads "Connector discovery completed without finding any connectors. Please check your Internet connection and try again."

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/679236/e2500dba-2ee9-488c-9003-e6cd9c1dce6e)

I am really just providing this update as a known issue to help others potentially find it since the plan to fully ditch this functionality soon means it probably isn't worth doing anything else.

title: Name of org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.activity does not reflect is contents
body:
The `org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.activity` feature's name is simply `Mylyn Commons` - but this feature is the activity tracker and the name of the feature should probably reflect that.

https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/adbfdf433caeccd3e808cad3aabb37c52d447411/mylyn.commons/org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.activity-feature/feature.properties#L11-L12

title: Introduce standard "YYY Developer Resources" features that contains source bundles
body:
As discussed [here](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/168#issuecomment-1567255060) we need to introduce "YYY Developer Resources" features and then remove "SDK" features.

* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.builds.sdk` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.builds.feature.source`
* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.sdk` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.commons.feature.source`
* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.context.sdk` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.context.feature.source`
* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.reviews.sdk.feature` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.reviews.feature.source`
* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.sdk_feature` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.tasks.feature.source`
* [x] `org.eclipse.mylyn.versions.sdk` -> `org.eclipse.mylyn.versions.feature.source`

title: NA
body: I would like to do this together with revising feature's content/ids. So, this effort doesn't fit 3.26.1 service release.

title: Exceptions when closing Task List view
body:
I am getting an  "Widget is disposed" and "Not properly disposed SWT resource" exception when closing the task list view, either by closing the view or exiting Eclipse. You may need to run garbage collector to see the "Not properly disposed SWT resource" when just closing the view. 

Of course many users will still be closing this new view early on as they won't know where it came from, so having exceptions around it simply closing would be unfortunate. However, because the "Widget is disposed" only seems to happen if you have any tasks in the view it may be deemed less severe.

We can try to integrate with Eclipse MPC later.

@BeckerFrank @wimjongman @merks  WDYT?

title: Create Java->Code Style configuration for Java 17 and other best practices
body:
The Mylyn workspace is using the default Eclipse 'Code Style' settings for 'Code Cleanup' and 'Formatting' (which seem to be stuck in the JavaSE-1.5 era ???)

With Java17 now the default for the project there are a lot of settings that we can take advantage of to create cleaner code.

title: NA
body:
I exported CleanUp and Formatter  locally but GitHub won't allow me to add to the issue *&^%^(

I don't know the Eclipse internals enough as how to set up the projects to use them though.

@BeckerFrank 
Not sure where to go from here??

title: NA
body:
> I exported CleanUp and Formatter locally but GitHub won't allow me to add to the issue *&^%^(
> 
> I don't know the Eclipse internals enough as how to set up the projects to use them though.
> 
> @BeckerFrank Not sure where to go from here??

I think we have the settings on the single project in the .settings folder.
Can you place the exported file in the project org.eclipse.mylyn.releng so that I can try to import the file and look how we can set it for all projects.

title: NA
body:
Are you trying to create project-specific settings?  That’s a lot of copying to manage! 

This can also be set globally but then we would want to do that in the Oomph setup so that we all have it configured the same way. 

Will this change the save options such that any file we touch will be formatted with new formatting?

title: NA
body: Project-specific settings are best because there is no special setup required. But keeping them consistent is not trivial.

title: NA
body:
I created CodeStyleTemplates folder in org.eclipse.mylyn.releng in branch 200_CodeStyle.

From the email chain there doesn't seem an easy way to apply any code style configs globally. This is more of PoC as to what  I would like to see. How it is implemented/maintained I have no idea.

The settings should apply as soon as you save any changes.

Might be a good idea to do a global cleanup at some point

title: NA
body:
I think we can use the following.

-  use one project as the source and set here the wanted local settings for CleanUp and Formatter
- create a script that replace the files org.eclipse.jdt.ui.prefs and org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs in all java projects
- if needed we can instead of the replace only do a delete and insert of the  CleanUp and Formatter Settings 

For new Java projects we must copy the two files to the new project.

Thoughts?

title: NA
body:
+1 for project specific settings. 
Yes, they require more effort to sync but guarantees that changes done in any Eclipse IDE will use the same settings. I know that some people create linked .pref file that points to a common file, but I have no practical experience with this solution.

@gnl42 it is a bit tricky to discuss the change in this form.
Could you please highlight somehow the difference between current and suggested settings? Perhaps you can create a PR for one project to let us see what exactly we try to introduce.

title: NA
body:
I add the defaults as a separate files.

- eclipse-builtin-Formatter.xml
- java-builtin-Fromatter.xml   sorry typo :-( 
- builtin-cleanup.xml

Compare of the Formatter with the Eclipse Formatter shows the following changes.
`        <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.use_tabs_only_for_leading_indentations" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.char" value="space"/> `


Compare Cleanup
`        <setting id="cleanup.array_with_curly" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.use_autoboxing" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.remove_trailing_whitespaces_ignore_empty" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.system_property_file_encoding" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.no_super" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.stringconcat_to_textblock" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.system_property_path_separator" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.instanceof" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.boolean_literal" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.no_string_creation" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.use_unboxing" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.system_property_line_separator" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.map_cloning" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.try_with_resource" value="true"/> `
`        <setting id="cleanup.use_this_for_non_static_method_access" value="true"/> `

title: NA
body:
1.
```
<setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.use_tabs_only_for_leading_indentations" value="true"/>
<setting id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.char" value="space"/>
```
Does it mean that we will need to replace Tab with Spaces everywhere? If yes - what is the benefit?

2.
```
<setting id="cleanup.multi_catch" value="true"/>
```
Please, don't. People will just stop thinking what are they catching at all. Trivial example is `InvocationTargetException` and `InterruptedException` : they need different handling by contract.

3.
```
<setting id="cleanup.make_parameters_final" value="true"/>
<setting id="cleanup.make_variable_declarations_final" value="true"/>
```

I'm all for immutability, but `final` keyword everywhere looks excessive.

4.
```
<setting id="cleanup.use_var" value="true"/>
```
I understand, for some cases type for variable declaration looks excessive, but do we want all the code to always use `var` ?

title: Eclipse Dash action should not cause build failure
body:
Actually I don't like this decision. 
But I do not see good alternative at the moment, because in case of any false positive the PR is blocked (see #201 for example).

So, let's configure Eclipse Dash action to not fail

title: NA
body: You can change it back when the backlog is clear.

title: NA
NA
body:
> @HannesWell is it possible to configure license check to not fail using[ standard action](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/blob/3bfff8a8fcd1e51f77f353bcce76f89c6f9b59f5/.github/workflows/licensecheck.yml#L19)? 

It is right that currently the workflow always fails if the license-vetting could not succeed.
I can look into adding a configuration option to not fail the build if the license check has failed, next week, but it might not be straight forward because I have to check if this might break assumption for downstream code.
But I then would be concerned about being not aware of license-check failures, because I assume that nobody really checks the workflow logs if interaction is required.
Not vetted licenses in-between releases are not a problem AFAIK, but when you perform a release all dependencies should be vetted and a failure in the license-check is IMHO a good heads up.

In general you are free to ignore the failing license-check workflow, when you want to merge a PR. That was actually the main reason why I created a separate workflow independent of the regular build+text workflow, so that one can see immediately that there is only a license-vetting issue, but technically the change is fine because the build+test workflow succeeds.
If one does the license-check in the same workflow as building and testing it would indeed be annoying because one would never know if there are technical issues occur later in the pipeline, hidden by the license-check failure. But due to the separate failure you can distinguish pressingly. 

It looks like you could exclude a failing license check from blocking the merge:
https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/managing-protected-branches/managing-a-branch-protection-rule

Personally I think that this is a good compromise. It does not fail your build+tests, but you are still aware of the situation.
But of course if you insist I can build in an option to not fail the workflow if license vetting fails.

title: Using Docker images of Jenkins for unit tests
body:
Following some comments in #203 regarding the state of our current Jenkins server used for the unit tests I wondered if Docker images could be used during the Mylyn build.      

I've come up with a working PoC using TestContainer to launch Jenkins as docker container and using that container to run a couple of of JUnit tests successfully. 

It runs fine under Eclipse but when I try build Mylyn with Maven the build blows up on the modified target file.
`[ERROR] Failed to resolve target definition file:/E:/workspaces/eclipse-mylyn/mylyn-main/git/org.eclipse.mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn-target/mylyn-e4.28.target: Artifact MavenArtifactFacade [...], IncludeDependencyScope = [compile, runtime, test], MissingManifestStrategy = GENERATE, IncludeSource = true is not a valid jar file`

Also I don't know if it will run using the Mylyn Jenkins instance used for the builds?

Is this something worth exploring more? Or is it just a wild idea?

George
_Originally posted by @gnl42 in https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/issues/203#issuecomment-1627643286_

body:
Do the servers on mylyn.org talk to each other? If not, why do we need a network?
And if they do, could we not set up the test image to run them all?

How does this sound @BeckerFrank @sddavis @ruspl-afed :

===
The Mylyn project currently uses servers  (gerrit, bugzilla jenkin, etc.) running on mylyn.org, a server sponsored by Tasktop.com, for the unit test validation of its code.
Tasktop have said that they no longer maintaining the server and has indicated that they will retire the server at some point in the future.

One possible solution to this is run the unit test against services running on Docker images. I've implemented a Proof Of Concept of this using [TestContainers](https://testcontainers.com/) that runs on fine my local machine against a Jenkins server docker image, but when the Jenkins server on https://ci.eclipse.org/mylyn ran the code it complained with:

> 79513 [main] INFO org.testcontainers.dockerclient.DockerMachineClientProviderStrategy - docker-machine executable was not found on PATH ([/opt/tools/java/openjdk/jdk-17/latest/bin, /opt/tools/apache-maven/latest/bin, /opt/tools/java/openjdk/jdk-17/latest/bin, /opt/tools/apache-maven/latest/bin, /usr/local/sbin, /usr/local/bin, /usr/sbin, /usr/bin, /sbin, /bin]) 
> 79547 [main] ERROR org.testcontainers.dockerclient.DockerClientProviderStrategy - Could not find a valid Docker environment. Please check configuration. Attempted configurations were: UnixSocketClientProviderStrategy: failed with exception InvalidConfigurationException (Could not find unix domain socket). Root cause NoSuchFileException (/var/run/docker.sock) DockerDesktopClientProviderStrategy: failed with exception NullPointerException (Cannot invoke "java.nio.file.Path.toString()" because the return value of "org.testcontainers.dockerclient.DockerDesktopClientProviderStrategy.getSocketPath()" is null) As no valid configuration was found, execution cannot continue.

When I look at https://wiki.eclipse.org/Jenkins I see:

> I want to build a custom Docker image (with docker build), but it does not work. What should I do?
>   You cannot currently build images on the cluster (i.e. docker build does not work). We plan to address this shortcoming shortly. 

This note was added to the page in 2018.

So I'm wondering if the docker engine could be installed on the Jenkins server to be used as a possible  replacement for mylyn.org?

If this is not possible, is there any other way a Test instance for the servers could be set up on the Eclipse infrastructure that can be accessed by the Mylyn build?

Thanks
   George

title: duplicate elements shown in context preview page when duplicates exist in the model
body:
This issue was created in gitlab.eclipse.org by Eugene Kuleshov
(see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=256887.
Also referenced:
- https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=173325
- https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=425554
- https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=213097

`I am working with projects organized hierarchically on disk. For example:

foo-parent
  foo-module1
    src
      resources
  foo-module2
    src
      resources

This structure give 3 projects in Eclipse:

foo-parent
foo-module1
foo-module2

Note that such project layout is quite popular in Maven community.

Now, when resource in foo-module1/src/resources is changed, e.g. using one of Eclipse editors, this same resource is forcefully shown in the package explorer two times, first in foo-module1/src/resources and second in foo-parent/foo-module1/src/resources

This clutters package explorer view and also forcing user to deal with this clutter, basically distracting him form the main task.`

title: NA
body:
In your case, you will also get each search result twice.

In such a case, I always filter out the foo-module* projects from the foo-parent project. Did you try this?

title: NA
body:
@gnl42 

Lots of people don't know about filters.  You can do that via the properties of a project:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-mylyn/org.eclipse.mylyn/assets/208716/88d50f39-e4e9-442b-a107-381e168e65b6)

Here I have two nested projects but I don't want to show them twice, so in the parent project, I filter out the children of the nested projects so that I still see the placeholder folder, but not the "duplicate" contents.  Here's a filter expression which uses regular expressions:

```
maven-osgi/org.eclipse.orbit.maven.generator/.*|maven-bnd/org.eclipse.orbit.maven.bnd.generator/.*
```

Thanks. I'll have to try it out.

title: Rework 3rd party libs dependencies
body:
* switch from `Require-Bundle` to `Import-Package`
* ensure that we don't have 3rd party bundles referenced in `feature.xml`
* ensure that we do publish required 3rd party bundles in `category.xml`

title: Mylyn should detect Compare Editor input change
body:
### Environment

Eclipse Committers Package 2023-06
Mylyn workspace configured by Oomph

### Steps to repeat

* modify several files _before_ activating any task context
* activate task
* go to Git Staging view
* double click on changed file -> its opened with Compare Editor and added to context
* double click on another file -> Compare Editor renewed

### Expected

file added to context

### Actual

file not added to context

### Workaround

Close Compare Editor and double click on changed file again

title: JUnit's assertThat is deprecated
body: There are more than 500 uses of [deprecated](https://jsparrow.us19.list-manage.com/track/click?u=90c9a79088ea3b2e9b03a176c&id=d0e45b5a2b&e=eec9da9571) ```org.junit.Assert.assertThat``` in Mylyn codebase. It should be replaced with Hamcrest's method. That is also a step for #51 because [there is no ```assertThat()``` in JUnit 5](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#writing-tests-assertions-third-party)..

title: NA
body: Fixed by #253

title: java.lang.Boolean constructor is deprecated
body: There are several uses of [deprecated](https://docs.oracle.com/javase%2F9%2Fdocs%2Fapi%2F%2F/java/lang/Boolean.html) ```Boolean(boolean value)``` constructor in Mylyn codebase. It should be replaced with ```Boolean.valueOf(boolean value)```.
